title: CVE-2022-32208: FTP-KRB bad message verification

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

activities.message:
Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!

If data connection is affected you will be able to "download" parts of the heap (at least `buf->data` => `buf->data` + `filesize`). Assuming this an app where you only have access to the downloaded files, it could allow leaking secrets from the heap. Luckily only `sec_recv` is affected so the impact is limited to client side.
I actually question if there are curl users using krb-ftp at all.

> The attacker merely needs to find a position in the FTP protocol where ftpcode 599 doesn't lead to connection termination

That seems to be the case, but can the server do that at an early enough point so that it can actually accomplish anything after? Is it really so "merely"  to find such a place that allows the server to actually do something maliciously?

> I actually question if there are curl users using krb-ftp at all.

It probably is very very rare indeed.

> That seems to be the case, but can the server do that at an early enough point so that it can actually accomplish anything after? Is it really so "merely" to find such a place that allows the server to actually do something maliciously?

Very little. Attack against the FTP download itself probably is more fruitful as an attack vector. If my understanding on how this works is correct, the attacker would have full control on the file content sent, except for the 5 first chars that will be se to "599 \0".

This attack seems a little convoluted. If there's a MITM already serving a working FTP-KRB to the extent that it can insert an error at a selectable  point, why not just keep the fully legitimate connection and *not* cause an error and just serve bad content?

My understanding is that FTP-KRB has encryption (confidential/private) and integrity checking (safe/private). For this to work `gss_unwrap()` return code must be checked correctly. Since it is not, the attacker can bypass the integrity and encryption and pass unsigned cleartext data, and it is processed as-is (barring the 5 bytes set as described). This would not be possible if the error checking was done correctly.

FTP-KRB is obscure enough thing so I am not 100% sure about this. The `CURLOPT_KRBLEVEL` at least suggests this:
```
    "clear" - Clear - neither Integrity nor Privacy
    "safe" - Safe - Integrity without Privacy
    "confidential" - Confidential - Privacy without Integrity
    "private" - Private - Integrity and Privacy
```
However, I must admit that I currently have no way to test this in practice, so I could be wrong here.
... but in order to make the `gss_unwrap()` function return this error at the exact right point in time, the server must already be MITMed or be malicious, won't it?

>  but in order to make the gss_unwrap() function return this error at the exact right point in time, the server must already be MITMed or be malicious, won't it?

Yes this attack requires man in the middle position.

Since the data is read from socket directly this is easily doable for the attacker. The attacker merely needs to wait for the packet that is associated with the data transfer (it should be easy to identify from the 32bit packet size) and then replace the wrapped data with the malicious payload of up to 4 GB in size. Once `gss_unwrap()` fails, the first 5 bytes will be replaced with `599 \0` but other than that the attacker sent payload is received as the downloaded data.
Ah, do you mean a TCP MITM for either the "clear" or "safe" krb levels? Don't the "stronger" and more proper levels "confidential" and "private" setup an encrypted channel?

Yes they do, but the whole channel isn't encrypted even then, there is still control messaging in clear (such as the token type) etc. For example see:
https://github.com/krb5/krb5/blob/f8ecc0ae74c7ebd84f042e28079aa6b4b2ae405c/src/lib/gssapi/krb5/k5unseal.c#L409

In fact the most likely result is that the token header structure will be considered corrupt and `gss_unwrap` will return `GSS_S_DEFECTIVE_TOKEN`. Either way, the result is that curl will process the bogus message as unwrapped data.

It'd really be great to be able to verify this in practice though.

Wait did I accidentally click somewhere? I didn't mean to close. oopsie.

Yeah right I meant to add a comment not close there. I think I accidentally clicked on add comment somehow.

Aha. What a clunky format.

But: since it comes in that token/message format, this MITM attack is then very "low resolution". Depending entirely on how large the messages are.

I mean, when the attacker changes the token or breaks the message in order to trigger curl to insert that "599 " into the stream, and that 599 is meant to *not* make curl just bail out, it can only do this on a per token/message level, right? It makes this attack even harder to pull off to actually make something deliberately bad with it.

I'm not entirely sure what you mean with "low resolution" here. If you mean to say that this somehow depends on the size of the original message, no, that is not a limitation. The attacker can choose how large message they will spoof. The size can be 1 to 2^32-1 bytes. See:

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/7007324a6a50693b089896fe078186bc8965d452/lib/krb5.c#L510

If the message is >= 4 bytes the first 5 chars will be forced to "599 \0" however:

https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/7007324a6a50693b089896fe078186bc8965d452/lib/krb5.c#L144

This appears to be a 1 byte heap overflow btw, as the strcpy will write 5th byte even if the buffer is allocated for 4 bytes. Likely totally unexploitable, however.
Here's a graphical representation of the issue. It might be easier to follow than my written explanation.

I checked a normal simple FTP download procedure with curl (test case 103). Out of the commands curl sends there, curl silently ignores a 599 response for two commands: `PWD` and `SIZE`. No other command accepts a 599 response undetected. In fact 599 triggers a failure in all other cases.

It indeed is hard to find this to be super useful in the control channel. The attack would be more fruitful against the actual downloaded data though. Even then part of it will be overwritten by the "599 \0" of course, which somewhat limits the usability of the attack.
@nyymi so the attacker can split `olen + data` in two and deliver as two separate `tampered_len + data` packets without it getting noticed?

It can't be split. This is due to the fact that the buffer length becomes (size_t)-1 on `gss_unwrap()` error. Thus  the attacker needs to send a single response that will satisfy the remainder of `conn->recv()` done on that connection. If curl `conn->recv()` more data than what the attacker provides the `memcpy` in `buffer_read` will hit unrelated heap (and if more and more data is `conn->recv()` it will eventually crash due to running out of mapped memory).

So in practice the attacker would need to provide "enough" data to satisfy the transfer they target. Adding padding to the end will solve this issue in most cases as there are only certain file formats that are parsed from the end towards the beginning. Of course the specific things targeted needs to survive the "599 \0".

Note that it is possible to target transfer in the middle, assuming the normal transfer is done in chunks (I presume it is). Then it would be possible to switch to attacker content at given position during the transfer. There would still be the "599 \0" in the buffer in the spot where the switch happens, but it would not be in the start of the file.  The attacker doesn't know the prior content being transferred making this kind of attack somewhat tricky. If the attacker knows what is being transferred they will be able to pull this variant off as well.

Suitable targets for this attack are for example text based scripts that would later get executed explicitly (without relying on a shebang).

Shell scripts would work as well as for example perl.

Shell script:
```
$ hexdump -Cv test.sh
00000000  35 39 39 20 00 3b 0a 65  63 68 6f 20 22 66 6f 6f  |599 .;.echo "foo|
00000010  22 0a                                             |".|
00000012
$ sh test.sh
test.sh: 1: 599: not found
foo
```

Perl script:
```
$ hexdump -Cv test.pl
00000000  35 39 39 20 00 3b 0a 70  72 69 6e 74 20 22 66 6f  |599 .;.print "fo|
00000010  6f 5c 6e 22 3b 0a                                 |o\n";.|
00000016
$ perl test.pl
foo
```
I'm sure there are various other suitable targets as well, but these are the obvious ones I could think of right now.

It's a way more aggressive MITM though, to pull that off. An FTP MITM that can intercept the data connection for a passive FTP transfer without seeing the control connection would need to just unconditionally accept connections to just about any port.
Hm, that second check should probably only do `if(buf->size < 0)`
That won't work because `buf->size` is `size_t`, and thus cannot be < 0.
didn't work exactly like that, a v2 is attached
v3

> It's a way more aggressive MITM though, to pull that off. An FTP MITM that can intercept the data connection for a passive FTP transfer without seeing the control connection would need to just unconditionally accept connections to just about any port.

Sure, this part is relatively "easy" to pull off though since you can just examine the traffic and identify the GSS-API traffic (the headers etc are in clear). The more difficult part is determining for which data connections to replace the downloaded data for. If you have any prior knowledge what is being downloaded this makes it easier. Fully blind attack will be far more difficult to target since just replacing any download with for example evil zip files won't get you far.

You would learn this information if the mode is `clear` (neither Integrity nor Privacy) or `safe` (Integrity without Privacy) for some reason. If encryption is in place they really need to know what is being downloaded some other way (timed transfer repeating every n minutes, specific type of download always being done to specific host or something along those lines). Either way some additional information is likely needed for successful exploitation.
v3 looks ok to me.

Thinking:

CWE-924: Improper Enforcement of Message Integrity During Transmission in a Communication Channel
That looks suitable indeed.
Advisory draft

Looking good.

I dunno if it would be relevant to mention that this vulnerability could also be used to expose unrelated application heap memory content locally? This is usually not a problem of course, but it could be prudent to mention this impact as well.
How exactly do you do that? Or maybe put another way: how do you propose we add that mention?

Maybe something along the lines of: "This vulnerability may also lead to out of bound memory accesses, which may lead to local exposure of unrelated heap contents or application crash."

I'm not sure about this though, since this may lead to unnecessary alarm.

Since I accidentally but stupidly committed a draft version of the advisory for this issue to the master branch of the curl web site git repository a few days ago (only to realize it today). We have decided to speed up the release process and instead do it on June 27. I'm very sorry for this.

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
